content.webTitle: Downton Abbey recap: series five, episode eight – a fittingly weird finale

fields.headline: Downton Abbey recap: series five, episode eight – a fittingly weird finale
fields.bodyText: SPOILER ALERT: This blog is for people watching Downton Abbey series five. Don’t read on if you haven’t seen series five, episode eight. Read Viv Groskop’s episode seven blog here. What? You have got to be kidding me. After all that, the bloody dog is already dead? And we’re expected to behave as if we know about it and don’t mind? I had to check twice that I was not watching the wrong episode. Pet’s tombstones? What? This is offensive. One minute Rose is getting engaged and Isis is a bit poorly. (OK, she had a cancer diagnosis. But I assumed that would turn out to be wrong.) Now Rose is virtually pregnant and divorced. And Isis is four feet under. RIP Isis. Gone and already forgotten. (But not by this blog.) This feature-length finale was, even by Downton’s standards, odd. But also oddly pleasing. Like watching a pilot for a completely different TV series that just happened to feature some of the characters and plot lines from Downton Abbey. It felt like a big set-up for the recently announced series six and/or the Christmas special. Denker is evidently the new O’Brien. Jailbird Anna is the new Bates. Dame Maggie is the new Rose. Several thousand new plotlines surfaced and were put to bed in this blink-and-you’ve-missed-it outing. Denker is doing suspicious things with the new footman! Daisy is thinking about leaving! The police keep coming to interview Anna! The Ill-Defined Suitor is getting married! Who cares! Where’s the other Ill-Defined Suitor when you need him? As usual, the strongest moments were the intimate scenes that erupted into sudden violence or repressed passion. Shrimpy did well here: “Get down, you cat!” But the business with the caught-in-clinch-with-Stringfellows-stripper photographs? Just not believable. I can’t help thinking that in the mid 1920s this would have been: a) very difficult to arrange for a grumpy, impoverished aristocratic woman recently arrived from India, and b) far more of a scandal. Rose behaved as if a dodgy selfie had been posted on Facebook. Back at the house, the police came to visit for the 485th time. Not Sergeant Willis again. He has virtually moved in. “We hoped this was over.” “So did I , Mr Bates.” So did we all. These are very strange policemen who interview four people at the same time and keep asking Mrs Hughes what she thinks about everything. Although really that’s fair enough as Mrs Hughes is The All-Seeing Eye Who Knows Everything. It was only a matter of time before Anna found herself in the nick, with nary an ill-defined contraceptive device to keep her company. “Take your place in the line.” No! Not Anna! Don’t pick out No.1! It was not Anna, it was Keyser Soze. It has been an entire series of “Who pushed Mini-Den under the bus?” If the Christmas Special doesn’t answer the question once and for all, I will throw a mince pie at the television, one with Uncle Julian’s name iced on it. That will be the second one. The first one was for Matthew and the bakery truck. The ridiculous business of (the otherwise wonderful) Mrs Patmore and the memorial was finally, finally resolved. Would the Earl of Grantham really talk to the cook about this? And would he really have commissioned the stone? Oh, who cares, when we can see Mrs Patmore emote like Meryl Streep in Sophie’s Choice, topped off with a double-take for the Earl of Grantham as he inspects the Edith Doppelganger Deja-Vu Impostor Child. Some lovely stolen moments. A beautiful scene between Dame Maggie and Penelope Wilton about lost chances. Loved the mention of Sybil and her evening pyjamas. Enjoyed the affection between Rose and her father: “This is where I become his wife.” And there was a nostalgic reminder of the relationship between Mary and Carson, which we haven’t seen for a while. I really, really wanted Denker to turn out to be a massive predatory cougar. But she just liked a free drink. After watching this programme for five series, don’t we all? Random subplot alert Big up Daisy’s Marxist-feminist revolution! “London is full of possibilities ... Sometimes I think my life has no possibilities at all ... I feel as if I’ve been down a coal-hole and someone’s opened a lid and brought me into the sunlight ... ” PARKLIFE! “I could get a job in London ... I’m handing in my notice ... There’s a whole world out there ...” PARKLIFE! What? Daisy can’t leave! She doesn’t know how to do anything apart from spout Wikipedia quotes she has picked up from Molesley and the Uppity Schoolteacher. Thankfully she realised this herself before the end of the episode. Not before we had witnessed great emotion from Mrs Patmore. “I am crying because I don’t want you to leave. I’ll miss you ... Don’t concern yourself. I’ll get over it.” If she cries any more the spinach souffle will turn sour. Surprise character development The Russian Silver Fox is back! And he’s a sucker for a lavender day dress. “I wish to spend my final years with you. As a friend. As a lover. I don’t seek scandal. Only love.” Blimey. What a face on Dame Maggie! She looked 21 years old again. If this isn’t a wedding on the Christmas special, I will throw an entire box of mince pies at the television, all iced with the words “Gratuitous Emotional Heightening”. (I am a whizz with the piping bag.) Golden eyebrow of the week award Mary wins this week. And so takes the golden tweezer award for the entire series. All thanks to her dismissal of the waiter in Rules when he was interrupting the obscene photographs to take the order: “Are you ready to order?” “May we have a few more moments?” But the expression on her face when Mrs Hughes announced that Anna was about to be arrested? Open-mouth, high-browed. Priceless. Close runner-up: the Earl of Grantham’s expression of quivering disgust when he realised that Edith has birthed a child by the Disappeared-to-Germany-and-Now-Dead Editor. Excuse me, could you just repeat that awkward line of dialogue? • “Why does she have to carry on as if she’d invented motherhood?” Queen Bitch is not impressed by Edith’s Gina Ford act. • “There’s fun to be had around here if you know where to look for it.” Is Denker angling to be Thomas’s pimp? • “Divorce signifies weakness, degradation, scandal, failure.” Don’t sit on the fence, Lord Sinderby! • “Do you find it difficult to get staff?” “Not really. But, then, we’re Jewish. So we pay well.” Rose’s new mother-in-law is a total dude. • “Don’t tell Edith you’ve guessed.” Seeing as the Earl of Grantham doesn’t seem to have told anyone that Isis is dead, I don’t think he’ll have any trouble keeping the secret of Marigold. Next week There is no next week. Isis’s backside has waggled for the last time. (Or has it? Will they change the opening credits?) Series six has been commisioned and filming begins soon. Coming next: the ITV charity sketch with Hugh Bonneville and George Clooney. And the Christmas special, which is traditionally scheduled at the time on Christmas Day when you are just about to fall into a sherry coma. Which is appropriate, really.
